Abstract: Aleksandr Lebedev, 85, who rose from a peasant's son to become first Soviet deputy minister of higher education, and Maria Kovalyova, a 21-year-old student in Moscow, share a dismay at Russia's slipshod democracy and bandit capitalism over the last decade; photos; chronology of Russian history since 1917 (M)
Snippet: Aleksandr Lebedev, 85, who rose from a peasant's son to become first Soviet deputy minister of higher education, and Maria Kovalyova, a 21-year-old student in Moscow, share a dismay at Russia's slipshod democracy and bandit capitalism over the las...
LeadParagraph: Revolution and change convulsed Russia twice in the last century, the first time in 1917, when the Bolsheviks seized power, and then in 1991, when the communist system they introduced, at such a fearful cost, collapsed under its own weight. Each time ordinary lives were swept up, sometimes swept away. In midcentury, millions died, killed by war, famine and a totalitarian regime.

Headline.Main: 'We Accepted That We Were Working for the Good of the Country'
Headline.PrintHeadline: REFLECTIONS: RUSSIA; 'We Accepted That We Were Working for the Good of the Country'
